info.name: My Salesforce Client Demos
info.description:
### Demo Steps

1. Create Scratch Org
    1. Clone this Github ([https://github.com/eltoroit/realTimeSalesforce](https://github.com/eltoroit/realTimeSalesforce)) repo
    2. Create a new scratch org by running the `createOrg` script
        1. Install packages: `npm install`
        2. Ensure you have [ETCopyData](https://github.com/eltoroit/etcopydata) to load the data for the new scratch org.
        3. Create scratch org: `npm run createOrg`
2. Setup ORG
    1. Verify your email address is associated with the scratch org owner `user user`
    2. Grab the credentials for the connected app
        1. Navigate to `Setup> Apps > App Manager` (_**/lightning/setup/NavigationMenus/home**_)
        2. Find the connected app named `RealTimeSalesforce`
        3. Click `Manage Consumer Details` and follow instructions, then copy the values in a file in VS Code
    3. Enable Username/Password oAuth flow
        1. Navigate to `Setup > OAuth and OpenID Connect Settings` (_**/lightning/setup/OauthOidcSettings/home**_)
        2. Toggle `Allow OAuth Username-Password Flows` to ON.
3. Update variables in Postman
    1. In VS Code, open the file `etLogs/_user.json`
    2. On a browser, [login to your](https://identity.getpostman.com/login) Postman account
    3. Create a new collection and import the JSON file **PUT LINK HERE**
    4. In Postman, open the `variables` tab for that collection
    5. For these variables, ensure the \`Initial values\` column has these values:
        1. url: `https://test.salesforce.com`
        2. username: Copy this from the _user.json file
        3. password: Copy this from the _user.json file
        4. clientId: This is the `Consumer Key` obtained in the previous step
        5. clientSecret: This is the `Consumer Secret` obtained in the previous step
        6. SecretToken: Leave this blank because the IP Ranges have been set in the Admin profile
    6. Click `Reset all`to copy the values from `Initial Value` to `Current Value`
        1. ❌ **WARNING**: do not click the persist button or you need to go back to the previous step since this does the opposite operation from what we want.
4. Validate settings are correct
    1. Find the `/UNPW OAuth Tester` request in this collection
    2. Click `Send`
    3. Validate
        1. You should receive a valid `access_token`
        2. The `instance_url` should be valid for your scratch org
5. Now that we know the oAuth is properly configured, let Postman get its own access token
    1. Navigate to the `Authorization` tab for the collection
    2. At the bottom of the page, click the `Get New Access Token` button
    3. Follow the oAuth prompts
    4. Click `Proceed`
    5. Click `Use Token`
6. Let's use the access token inside Postman
    1. Find the `REST API/Query Account (OAuth)` request in this collection
    2. Click `Send`
    3. You should receive 2 records
7. Streaming API demo
    
    1. Postman must be using the `Desktop Agent` for the requests, make sure you set that and install the required software from here: [https://www.postman.com/downloads/postman-agent/](https://www.postman.com/downloads/postman-agent/)
    2. Re-execute the previous REST API query to ensure it works via the Desktop Agent
    3. The `Streaming API` folder has 2 subfolders:
        
        1. `Subscriber (Run This!)` is the actual implementation of Streaming API long-polling
            
            1. Open the Postman console to see the different requests/responses in action
            2. Select the `Pre-request Script` tab in this folder to configure the demo by indicating which event you want, and the replay Id.
            3. Click `Run`, a new window should appear
                
            4. Click `Run My Salesforce Client Demos` to see the requests/responses in action
        2. `Publisher` allows you to publish new events on the bus

body.raw:
<soapenv:Envelope xmlns:soapenv="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/" xmlns:urn="urn:enterprise.soap.sforce.com">
   <soapenv:Header>
      <urn:SessionHeader>
         <urn:sessionId>{{_soapSession}}</urn:sessionId>
      </urn:SessionHeader>
   </soapenv:Header>
   <soapenv:Body>
      <urn:query>
         <urn:queryString>SELECT Id, Name, BillingStreet, BillingCity, BillingState, BillingCountry, BillingPostalCode From Account WHERE Name = 'ELTORO.IT'</urn:queryString>
      </urn:query>
   </soapenv:Body>
</soapenv:Envelope>

request.description: Lists information about limits in your org. For each limit, this resource returns the maximum allocation and the remaining allocation based on usage. This resource is available in REST API version 29.0 and later for API users with the View Setup and Configuration permission

request.description:
Executes a series of REST API requests in a single call. You can use the output of one request as the input to a subsequent request. The response bodies and HTTP statuses of the requests are returned in a single response body. The entire request counts as a single call toward your API limits.
The requests in a composite call are called subrequests. All subrequests are executed in the context of the same user. In a subrequest’s body, you specify a reference ID that maps to the subrequest’s response. You can then refer to the ID in the url or body fields of later subrequests by using a JavaScript-like reference notation.

https://developer.salesforce.com/docs/atlas.en-us.api_rest.meta/api_rest/resources_composite_composite.htm

request.description:
Executes a series of REST API requests in a single call. You can use the output of one request as the input to a subsequent request. The response bodies and HTTP statuses of the requests are returned in a single response body. The entire request counts as a single call toward your API limits.
The requests in a composite call are called subrequests. All subrequests are executed in the context of the same user. In a subrequest’s body, you specify a reference ID that maps to the subrequest’s response. You can then refer to the ID in the url or body fields of later subrequests by using a JavaScript-like reference notation.

https://developer.salesforce.com/docs/atlas.en-us.api_rest.meta/api_rest/resources_composite_composite.htm

Composite graphs provide an enhanced way to perform composite requests, which execute a series of REST API requests in a single call.
Regular composite requests allow you to execute a series of REST API requests in a single call. And you can use the output of one request as the input to a subsequent request.

Composite graphs extend this by allowing you to assemble a more complicated and complete series of related objects and records.

Composite graphs also enable you to ensure that the steps in a given set of operations are either all completed or all not completed. This avoids requiring you to check for a mix of successful and unsuccessful results.

Regular composite requests have a limit of 25 subrequests. Composite graphs increase this limit to 500. This gives a single API call much greater power.

https://developer.salesforce.com/docs/atlas.en-us.api_rest.meta/api_rest/resources_composite_graph_introduction.htm

body.raw:
<soapenv:Envelope xmlns:soapenv="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/" xmlns:urn="urn:enterprise.soap.sforce.com">
   <soapenv:Header>
      <urn:SessionHeader>
         <urn:sessionId>{{_soapSession}}</urn:sessionId>
      </urn:SessionHeader>
   </soapenv:Header>
   <soapenv:Body>
      <urn:query>
         <urn:queryString>SELECT Id, Name, BillingStreet, BillingCity, BillingState, BillingCountry, BillingPostalCode From Account WHERE Name = 'ELTORO.IT'</urn:queryString>
      </urn:query>
   </soapenv:Body>
</soapenv:Envelope>

</soapenv:Envelope>
